fields.name: cumulative_mass_balance
fields.description:
Source: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
https://www.epa.gov/climate-indicators/climate-change-indicators-glaciers
fields.owidDisplaySettings: {"name": "Cumulative mass balance of U.S. glaciers", "unit": "meters of water equivalent", "includeInTable": true}

fields.name: 700m_ocean_heat_content_csiro
fields.description:
Source: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
https://www.epa.gov/climate-indicators/climate-change-indicators-ocean-heat

The original data series is published from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO).

CSIRO (Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation). 2016 update to data originally published in: Domingues, C.M., J.A. Church, N.J. White, P.J. Gleckler, S.E. Wijffels, P.M. Barker, and J.R. Dunn. 2008. Improved estimates of upper-ocean warming and multi-decadal sea-level rise. Nature 453:1090–1094. www.cmar.csiro.au/sealevel/thermal_expansion_ocean_heat_timeseries.html

Ocean heat content is measured in 10²² joules. For reference, one 10²² joules is equal to approximately 17 times the amount of energy used globally every year.

It is measured relative to the 1971–2000 average, which is set at zero for reference.
fields.owidDisplaySettings: {"name": "Heat content in the top 700 meters of the world’s oceans (CSIRO)", "unit": "10²² joules", "includeInTable": true}

fields.name: 700m_ocean_heat_content_iap
fields.description:
Source: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
https://www.epa.gov/climate-indicators/climate-change-indicators-ocean-heat

The original data series is published from the Institute of Atmopsheric Physics (IAP).

IAP (Institute of Atmospheric Physics). 2021 update to data originally published in: Cheng, L., K.E. Trenberth, J. Fasullo, T. Boyer, J. Abraham, and J. Zhu. 2017. Improved estimates of ocean heat content from 1960 to 2015. Science Advances 3(3):e1601545.

Ocean heat content is measured in 10²² joules. For reference, one 10²² joules is equal to approximately 17 times the amount of energy used globally every year.

It is measured relative to the 1971–2000 average, which is set at zero for reference.
fields.owidDisplaySettings: {"name": "Heat content in the top 700 meters of the world’s oceans (IAP)", "unit": "10²² joules", "includeInTable": true}

fields.name: 700m_ocean_heat_content_mrijma
fields.description:
Source: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
https://www.epa.gov/climate-indicators/climate-change-indicators-ocean-heat

The original data series is published from the Meteorological Research Institute/Japan Meteorological Agency.

MRI/JMA (Meteorological Research Institute/Japan Meteorological Agency). 2021. Global ocean heat content. www.data.jma.go.jp/gmd/kaiyou/english/ohc/ohc_global_en.html

Ocean heat content is measured in 10²² joules. For reference, one 10²² joules is equal to approximately 17 times the amount of energy used globally every year.

It is measured relative to the 1971–2000 average, which is set at zero for reference.
fields.owidDisplaySettings: {"name": "Heat content in the top 700 meters of the world’s oceans (MRI/JMA)", "unit": "10²² joules", "includeInTable": true}

fields.name: 700m_ocean_heat_content_noaa
fields.description:
Source: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
https://www.epa.gov/climate-indicators/climate-change-indicators-ocean-heat

The original data series is published from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). Global ocean heat and salt content. www.nodc.noaa.gov/OC5/3M_HEAT_CONTENT.

Ocean heat content is measured in 10²² joules. For reference, one 10²² joules is equal to approximately 17 times the amount of energy used globally every year.

It is measured relative to the 1971–2000 average, which is set at zero for reference.
fields.owidDisplaySettings: {"name": "Heat content in the top 700 meters of the world’s oceans (NOAA)", "unit": "10²² joules", "includeInTable": true}

fields.name: sea_level_rise_cw2011
fields.description:
Source: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)
https://www.climate.gov/news-features/understanding-climate/climate-change-global-sea-level

This series measures sea level rise from the Church and White (2011)'s reconstruction of 20th century sea level rise (https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/2005GL024826). The values are shown as change in sea level in millimeters compared to the 1993-2008 average.
fields.owidDisplaySettings: {"name": "Change in sea level compared to the 1993-2008 average (Church & White)", "unit": "mm", "zeroDay": "1800-01-01", "shortUnit": "mm", "yearIsDay": true, "includeInTable": true}

fields.name: sea_level_rise_uhslcfd
fields.description:
Source: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)
https://www.climate.gov/news-features/understanding-climate/climate-change-global-sea-level

This series measures sea level rise from the University of Hawaii's Sea Level Center Fast Track (http://uhslc.soest.hawaii.edu/data/?fd). The values are shown as change in sea level in millimeters compared to the 1993-2008 average.
fields.owidDisplaySettings: {"name": "Change in sea level compared to the 1993-2008 average (UHSLC)", "unit": "mm", "zeroDay": "1800-01-01", "shortUnit": "mm", "yearIsDay": true, "includeInTable": true}

fields.name: sea_level_rise_average
fields.description:
Source: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)
https://www.climate.gov/news-features/understanding-climate/climate-change-global-sea-level

This series measures the average sea level rise from two sources:
1. the University of Hawaii's Sea Level Center Fast Track (http://uhslc.soest.hawaii.edu/data/?fd).
2. Church and White (2011)'s historical reconstruction (https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/2005GL024826).

The values are shown as change in sea level in millimeters compared to the 1993-2008 average.
fields.owidDisplaySettings: {"name": "Change in sea level compared to the 1993-2008 average (average of UHSLC and Church & White)", "unit": "mm", "zeroDay": "1800-01-01", "shortUnit": "mm", "yearIsDay": true, "includeInTable": true}
